items.title: Drop embedded copy of libffi
items.body:
In macOS 10.9 and later (at least, haven't checked earlier versions) there's a copy of libffi that's shipped with the system with headers in the SDK. This means we no longer need our own copy of libffi.

I therefore want to drop the local copy of libffi in PyObjC 7.

items.title: (macOS 11) pthread_jit_write_protect_np
items.body: Investigate if pthread_jit_write_protect_np is needed for libffi closures on macOS 11. The session "Explore the new system architecture of Apple Silicon Macs" seems to indicate that this will be needed because memory cannot be writable and executable at the same time.

items.title: Memory leakage in Quartz
items.body:
Hi,

I am trying to debug an issue of successive application state collection with user activity. But I get a very bad memory leakage with every iteration to find top window and it's metadata.
Is there a way to release memory after getting the required info from objects.?

```
from memory_profiler import profile
import sys, time, Quartz, gc

def _get_active_window():
    k  = 0
    windows = Quartz.CGWindowListCopyWindowInfo(Quartz.kCGWindowListExcludeDesktopElements | Quartz.kCGWindowListOptionOnScreenOnly, Quartz.kCGNullWindowID)
    lwin = list(windows)
    del windows
    for win in range(len(lwin)):
        if lwin[win]['kCGWindowLayer'] == 0:
            #store lwin and move
            break

    return k

@profile
def main(n):
    for i in range(n):
        k = _get_active_window()

for i in range(100):
    main(10*i)
    gc.collect()

```

items.title: Cannot build pyobjc-framework-PubSub on macOS 10.15
items.body:
When trying to build and install pyobjc from source on macOS 10.15 with
```
pip install --no-binary :all: pyobjc==6.2
```
it fails with the following error:
```
error: option --single-version-externally-managed not recognized
```

[pyobjc-framework-PubSub/setup.py](https://github.com/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/blob/v6.2/pyobjc-framework-PubSub/setup.py#L21) declares `max_os_level="10.14"`. However [pyobjc/setup.py](https://github.com/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/blob/v6.2/pyobjc/setup.py#L112) doesn't list the framework as removed in 10.15. I guess pyobjc/setup.py should mark it as removed in 10.15 as well to avoid trying to install it.

items.title: metadata on custom objects
items.body:
(running python code inside an app written in ObjectivC)

I have an object with a property defined like this:
```
typedef NSObject<GSContainerProtocol> GSContainer;

@property (weak) GSContainer *parent;
```
If I access it from python, I get this:
```
print(anObject.parent())

>>> ObjCPointerWarning: PyObjCPointer created: at 0x6110000c8180 of type ^{NSObject=#}16@0:8
>>> <PyObjCPointer object at 0x119851490>
```

If I use the type definition directly, it works fine:
 ```
@property (weak) NSObject<GSContainerProtocol> *parent;
```
I notices that the signatures of `parent` are different:
With the typedef I get`b'^{NSObject=#}16@0:8'`
with the direct type I get this: `b'@16@0:8'`

Why is that different and is there a way to fix this on my end?

items.title: thread safety
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/294) by Georg Seifert (Bitbucket: [Schriftgestalt](https://bitbucket.org/Schriftgestalt), GitHub: [Schriftgestalt](https://github.com/Schriftgestalt)).**

----------------------------------------

**OC\_PythonUnicode.m**:53

```
    /* There is small race condition when an object is almost deallocated
     * in one thread and fetched from the registration mapping in another
     * thread. If we don't get the GIL this object might get a -dealloc
     * message just as the other thread is fetching us from the mapping.
     * That's why we need to grab the GIL here (getting it in dealloc is
     * too late, we'd already be dead).
     */
    /* FIXME: Should switch to __weak on OSX 10.7 or later, that should
     * fix this issue without a performance penalty.
     */
    /*
     * There is also a race condition on application shutdown between
     * the call to Py_Finalize (shutting down the interpreter) and the
     * cleanup performed by Cocoa, possible on other threads.
     */
```

‌

Is that really something that has to be handled on that level? I would expect that objC-objects have the same problem?

And setting a weak property is slightly slower but only noticeable with a lot objects. At least the weak setter shows up in my profiling here and there.

----------------------------------------

\(App written in objC, scripting with python\)

My document model has some list or dict properties that can be set from a python script. When that document is saved, I get a dead lock:

‌

```
Thread 1 Queue : com.apple.main-thread (serial)#0 0x00007fff791e2866 in __psynch_cvwait ()
```

items.title: Install fails on non-macOS platforms
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/291) by Flynn (Bitbucket: [zo7](https://bitbucket.org/zo7), GitHub: [zo7](https://github.com/zo7)).**

----------------------------------------

# Summary

Installing pyobjc-core on a non-macOS platform fails with:

```
Collecting pyobjc-core==6.1
  Downloading pyobjc-core-6.1.tar.gz (791 kB)
  ...
  ERROR: Command errored out with exit status 1:
  command: ...
  Complete output (2 lines):
  running egg_info
  error: PyObjC requires macOS to build
```

While this if of course reasonable because pyobjc is only meant for macOS, it can cause problems for projects when trying to pin dependencies \(e.g. using pip freeze, pip-tools, or pipenv\)

For example, consider a library `foolib` that is multi-platform, but requires `pyobjc-core` as a dependency \(and even restricts pyobjc’s installation to only macOS with `; sys_platform == "darwin"`\) If one was on macOS and wanted to pin dependencies with `foolib`, they may use:

```
$ pip install foolib
$ pip freeze > requirements.txt
$ cat requirements.txt
foolib==1.0
pyobjc-core==6.1
```

However, if a Linux user \(or CI system\) takes their requirements.txt file and tries to install it with `pip install -r requirements.txt`, it would fail because pyobjc raises an error.

\(in our case, someone on macOS added a requirement that uses pyobjc as a downstream dependency and broke CI\)

# Solution

On the user’s end, a quick fix is to manually edit the requirements.txt \(or requirements.in, Pipfile, etc.\) to explicitly add `pyobjc-core ; sys_platform == "darwin"` as a requirement and ensure it doesn’t get installed on non-macOS platforms.

For pyobjc, a more robust solution would be to allow installation on non-macOS platforms \(and not compile anything\) but raise an error at runtime when trying to use the library on non-macOS platforms.

items.title: Problem with protocols
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/290) by Georg Seifert (Bitbucket: [Schriftgestalt](https://bitbucket.org/Schriftgestalt), GitHub: [Schriftgestalt](https://github.com/Schriftgestalt)).**

----------------------------------------

I have a an app written in objectivc. It can contain plugins written in python. They define a class inheriting from NSObject and have to implement a protocol. 

```python
GlyphsGeneralPluginProtocol = objc.protocolNamed("GlyphsPlugin")

class GeneralPlugin (NSObject):
	__pyobjc_protocols__ = [GlyphsGeneralPluginProtocol]
```

This worked fine but now I get this error.

```
TypeError: First argument is not an 'objc.informal_protocol' but 'objc.formal_protocol'
```

“`GlyphsPlugin`”  is implemented in objectiveC like this:

```objective-c
@protocol GlyphsPlugin

@property (nonatomic, readonly) NSUInteger interfaceVersion;

- (void)loadPlugin;
@end
```

I’m using python 3.8.1 \(downloaded from python.org\) with pyobjc 6.1 \(installed via pip\).

Any idea what is causing this?

items.title: Objective-C Category broken, was working in pyobjc 4.2.1 with Python 3.6
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/286) by Riaz Rizvi (Bitbucket: [riazrizvi](https://bitbucket.org/riazrizvi), GitHub: [riazrizvi](https://github.com/riazrizvi)).**

----------------------------------------

The following code worked in pybojc version 4.2.1 with Python 3.6. 

‌

```
import AppKit as APK

class NSAttributedString(APK.objc.Category(APK.NSAttributedString)):
    def __add__(self,addTo):
        newMS=APK.NSMutableAttributedString.alloc().init()
        newMS.appendAttributedString_(self)
        newMS.appendAttributedString_(addTo)
        return newMS
```

‌

It now causes a segmentation fault if run in pyobjc 4.2.1 with Python 3.7\+, and it also crashes if run in pyobjc 6 with Python 3.6. So newer versions of pyobjc or of Python breaks Categories.

items.title: NSSavePanel problem on 10.15
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/282) by Ronald Oussoren (Bitbucket: [ronaldoussoren](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren), GitHub: [ronaldoussoren](https://github.com/ronaldoussoren)).**

----------------------------------------

As reported on pythonmac-sig by user Ben Byram-Wigfield:

The following two lines work in Mojave, but flag an error in Catalina:  
  

> from AppKit import NSSavePanel  
> panel = NSSavePanel.savePanel\(\)  

  
The error is:  
  
2019-10-29 18:24:22.275 Python\[6577:255233\] \*\*\* Assertion failure in \+\[NSServiceViewController currentAppIsViewService\], /BuildRoot/Library/Caches/com.apple.xbs/Sources/ViewBridge/ViewBridge-462/NSViewService.m:140  
2019-10-29 18:24:22.275 Python\[6577:255233\] \*\*\* Assertion failure in \+\[NSServiceViewController currentAppIsViewService\], /BuildRoot/Library/Caches/com.apple.xbs/Sources/ViewBridge/ViewBridge-462/NSViewService.m:140  
2019-10-29 18:24:22.342 Python\[6577:255347\] \+\[NSXPCSharedListener endpointForReply:withListenerName:\]: an error occurred while attempting to obtain endpoint for listener 'com.apple.view-bridge': Connection interrupted  
  
This is with PyObjC 5.2. I get the same error \(or not\) in python 2.7 and python 3.7.

items.title: Fix issues found by clang static analyser
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/281) by Ronald Oussoren (Bitbucket: [ronaldoussoren](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren), GitHub: [ronaldoussoren](https://github.com/ronaldoussoren)).**

----------------------------------------

The clang static analyser warns about some code in pyobjc-core \(not ran it on the framework wrappers yet\).  Fix those warnings.

items.title: Some symbols have unguarded availability with older deployment targets
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/278) by Maxime Belanger (Bitbucket: [Max Belanger](https://bitbucket.org/Max Belanger), ).**

----------------------------------------

We configure our build using `-Werror=unguarded-availability` and `MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET=10.10` to support deployment to down-level versions of macOS and to have confidence that unavailable symbols are not accidentally required. When recently trying out the new PyObjC 6.0 for 10.15 compatibility, we noticed the following error when building `pyobjc-framework-Cocoa` : 

‌

```
Modules/_AppKit_inlines.m:9:32: warning: 'NSDirectionalEdgeInsetsMake' is only available on macOS 10.15 or newer [-Wunguarded-availability-new]
     (PyObjC_Function_Pointer)&NSDirectionalEdgeInsetsMake},
                               ^
/Applications/Xcode-beta.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX10.15.sdk/System/Library/Frameworks/AppKit.framework/Headers/NSCollectionViewCompositionalLayout.h:74:35: note: 
      'NSDirectionalEdgeInsetsMake' has been marked as being introduced in macOS 10.15 here, but the deployment target is macOS 10.10.0
NS_INLINE NSDirectionalEdgeInsets NSDirectionalEdgeInsetsMake(CGFloat top, CGFloat leading, CGFloat bottom, CGFloat trailing) API_AVAILABLE(macos(10.15)) NS...
                                  ^
Modules/_AppKit_inlines.m:6:28: note: annotate 'function_map' with an availability attribute to silence this warning
static PyObjC_function_map function_map[] = {
                           ^
```

It appears that this symbol is not protected/guarded, at least according to `clang`.

‌

items.title: Build fails at macOS 10.15
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/276) by Andrey Popov (Bitbucket: [Andrey Popov](https://bitbucket.org/Andrey Popov), ).**

----------------------------------------

Installing this package via MacPorts at macOS 10.15 fails due to a compilation error. Here is the relevant part of the log:

‌

```
:info:build Modules/objc/helpers-foundation-nscoder.m:335:37: error: too many arguments to function call, expected 0, have 4
:info:build             (void)objc_msgSendSuper(&super,
:info:build                   ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ^~~~~~~
:info:build /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/SDKs/MacOSX10.15.sdk/usr/include/objc/message.h:66:1: note: 'objc_msgSendSuper' declared here
```

‌

The full build log is attached to the issue. It seems the interface has changed, and the function \`objc\_msgSendSuper\` now takes no arguments. MacPorts ships version 5.2 of pyobjc, but the head of the default branch also seems to be [affected](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/src/540efd23070fd3efef9dc111efcdbd102fd0a0a6/pyobjc-core/Modules/objc/helpers-foundation-nscoder.m#lines-49). My Xcode version is 11.1.

items.title: Run objc code in background and continue execution of Python code
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/273) by David3 (Bitbucket: [da_v_ide](https://bitbucket.org/da_v_ide), ).**

----------------------------------------

I have a working connection between my custom Objective-C and Swift written Framework and a Python project.  

Since I use sockets and asynchronous networking in the framework, I need to call a method \(that sets up a TCP server and then just waits for connections\) from Python \(which already works\) and then continues the Python code execution. Unfortunately, at the moment I have to call NSRunLoop.mainLoop.run\(\) to prevent the framework’s code from exiting right away which blocks the Python code’s further execution. Is there any possibility to have Objective-C code run in the background, either by calling the NSRunLoop.mainLoop.run\(\) from a background Thread in Python or a background thread in the objc framework?

‌

Or maybe a totally different solution?

‌

Thanks in advance!! Dave

items.title: NSOpenPanel.openPanel().setAllowedFileTypes_ no longer accept python array on 10.15 beta
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/272) by rndblnch (Bitbucket: [rndblnch](https://bitbucket.org/rndblnch), GitHub: [rndblnch](https://github.com/rndblnch)).**

----------------------------------------

I am signalling this issue since it is a regression on the pyobjc version that comes with the system python of Mac OS X 10.15 beta.

NSOpenPanel.openPanel\(\).setAllowedFileTypes\_ used to accept a python array, but no longer does.

so we now have to pass an NSArray instance, see:

[https://bitbucket.org/rndblnch/osx-presentation/issues/70/failing-to-open-open-file-dialog-on-1015](https://bitbucket.org/rndblnch/osx-presentation/issues/70/failing-to-open-open-file-dialog-on-1015)

[https://github.com/MagerValp/AutoDMG/issues/232](https://github.com/MagerValp/AutoDMG/issues/232)

items.title: Python Crashes When Using UNUserNotificationCenter
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/270) by Jerry Wang (Bitbucket: [pkqxdd](https://bitbucket.org/pkqxdd), GitHub: [pkqxdd](https://github.com/pkqxdd)).**

----------------------------------------

The Apple documentation for `UNUserNotificationCenter` specifies that one must use the `currentNotificationCenter` method to get an instance instead of instantiating one. However, the program crashes after calling this method.

Step to reproduce:

1. Open Python REPL
2. run

```python
import UserNotifications
UserNotifications.UNUserNotificationCenter.currentNotificationCenter()
```

After running this, Python interpreter receives SIGABRT with the following error 

> Terminating app due to uncaught exception 'NSInternalInconsistencyException', reason: 'Invalid parameter not satisfying: bundleProxy != nil'

Version: macOS 10.14.5, Python3.7, PyObjc 5.2

items.title: failed to setup if CommandLineTools is only setup and not Xcode.
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/269) by clément bouvier (Bitbucket: [clément bouvier](https://bitbucket.org/clément bouvier), ).**

----------------------------------------

So as to test different package by[ pkgsrc](https://www.pkgsrc.org), I usually use only Command Line Tools with different version that I can easy switch with xcode-select -s.

Some package build system such as [Joyent' one](https://pkgsrc.joyent.com) also use only Command Line Tools to build the packages to distribute \(the build log is available[ here](http://us-east.manta.joyent.com/pkgsrc/public/reports/Darwin/trunk/x86_64/20190724.2225/py37-pyobjc-core-5.1.2/build.log)\).

Changing xcodebuild into xcrun to determine the SDK path used does not seem have an impact \(xcrun -sdk macosx -show-sdk-path\).

Are there more implications to change xcodebuild into xcrun to find the sdk path?

items.title: Top Google result for PyObjC goes to old documentation
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/267) by Timmy Zhu (Bitbucket: [nattofriends](https://bitbucket.org/nattofriends), GitHub: [nattofriends](https://github.com/nattofriends)).**

----------------------------------------

Not sure if this is the right place to report this issue, but here goes anyway.

When searching for PyObjC on Google, the first result is the documentation hosted at https://pythonhosted.org/pyobjc/. This documentation was last updated for PyObjC 3.2.1. 

I noticed there is actually updated documentation built at https://pyobjc.readthedocs.io, but it is not even in the first page of search results.

Is it possible to update the pythonhosted.org documentation or possibly replace it with a permanent redirect to documentation that is regularly documented?

items.title: descr_templates isn't really constant
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/265) by Lawrence D'Anna (Bitbucket: [smoofra](https://bitbucket.org/smoofra), GitHub: [smoofra](https://github.com/smoofra)).**

----------------------------------------

descr_templates (in method-signature.m) isn't actually constant.
    
descr_templates is written to by setup_descr(), line 630 during initialization.   It should not be qualified const.

EDIT: 

The bug is that descr_templates gets written, not that it's qualified wrong

items.title: Overriding PyObjC_BUILD_RELEASE
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/263) by Sebastiaan Lokhorst (Bitbucket: [slokhorst](https://bitbucket.org/slokhorst), GitHub: [slokhorst](https://github.com/slokhorst)).**

----------------------------------------

I'm trying to create a [Homebrew formula](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/pull/35919) for an application that uses pyobjc-framework-Cocoa. As a part of Homebrew's continuous integration test, it attempts to build the formula on multiple macOS versions.

The [macOS Sierra build fails](https://jenkins.brew.sh/job/Homebrew%20Core%20Pull%20Requests/39054/version=sierra/testReport/junit/brew-test-bot/sierra/install___build_bottle_gajim/) because `setup.py` automatically sets `PyObjC_BUILD_RELEASE=1013` while it should be set to `1012`.

I've tried to manually set it by adding `-DPyObjC_BUILD_RELEASE=1012` to the `CFLAGS` environment variable, but that doesn't work because the version set by setup.py is put at the end of the CFLAGS and thus overrides my manual one.

Is there a way to manually set `PyObjC_BUILD_RELEASE`?

You can see the build log [here](https://jenkins.brew.sh/job/Homebrew%20Core%20Pull%20Requests/39054/version=sierra/testReport/junit/brew-test-bot/sierra/install___build_bottle_gajim/) (search for `Modules/_Foundation.m`).

items.title: applicationDidFinishLaunching_() not invoked with py2app
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/261) by Maarten den Braber (Bitbucket: [mdbraber](https://bitbucket.org/mdbraber), GitHub: [mdbraber](https://github.com/mdbraber)).**

----------------------------------------

(Crossposted to `py2app` as I'm not sure where this issue should fit)

Hi,

I've built a fairly simple Mac menubar app with `rumps`: http://github.com/mdbraber/radiobar. It works fine from the command line and mostly with `py2app`. The only thing that's not working is that `applicationDidFinishLaunching` method in the delegate is never called with `py2app`, but it's working fine from the commandline. I'm using Python 3.7.0, py2app 0.1.9 and py2objc 5.1.2 on macOS 10.14.2

You can check the `rumps` src file to see how it should be invoked (after `AppHelper.runEventLoop`. 

I've been scratching my head about this one and have been having a hard time debugging w/ pyobjc in the middle. Any help is greatly appreciated!

Maarten

items.title: Ensure framework wrappers have valid __spec__
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/259) by Ronald Oussoren (Bitbucket: [ronaldoussoren](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren), GitHub: [ronaldoussoren](https://github.com/ronaldoussoren)).**

----------------------------------------

The lazy importer does some tricky stuff, and breaks the package ```__spec__``` while doing that.  Make sure the ```__spec__``` is copied from the original module.

----------------------------------------

Consider `def webView_runJavaScriptAlertPanelWithMessage_initiatedByFrame_completionHandler_(self, webview, message, frame, completion_handler)` from https://developer.apple.com/documentation/webkit/wkuidelegate

Calling `completion_handler()` as is results in a `{TypeError}cannot call block without a signature`. What is a proper way to call this handler?

items.title: Use MAP_JIT on macOS 10.14
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/253) by Ronald Oussoren (Bitbucket: [ronaldoussoren](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren), GitHub: [ronaldoussoren](https://github.com/ronaldoussoren)).**

----------------------------------------

MAP_JIT is a mmap flag that’s apparently introduced in 10.14. The slides at https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2018/702/ mention this flag and the hardened runtime.  

With the hardened runtime and code signing mapping memory as writable and executable causes an error. 

To check: what happens when using MAP_JIT on older versions of macOS (10.9 - 10.13)?

Also: File issue with CPython for the same thing in ctypes when I have a proper solution for PyObjC.

items.title: Mojave: and NSSharingService Class 'OC_PythonUnicode' disallows secure coding. It must return YES from supportsSecureCoding
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/251) by Marc Van Olmen (Bitbucket: [marc_at_acclivitynyc](https://bitbucket.org/marc_at_acclivitynyc), ).**

----------------------------------------

Steps:

I have an Objective-c class that implements the following method:

```
#!objective-c

- (void)mailWithSharingServiceEmailAddress: (NSString *) emailAddress
                                   subject: (NSString *) subject
                                      body: (NSString *) body
                                      fileURL: (NSURL *) fileURL
{
    NSSharingService* sharingService = [NSSharingService sharingServiceNamed: NSSharingServiceNameComposeEmail];

    [sharingService setRecipients: @[emailAddress]];
    [sharingService setSubject:subject];
    [sharingService performWithItems: @[ body, fileURL]];
}

```

Then when I call this code from Python PyObjC 4.2.1 and also tried 5.0 the objects that are passed in are OC_PythonUnicode objects. My python environment is 64-bit Python 2.7.15.

This code worked fine under macOS High Sierra, but under Mojave this above code fails.

This is the error I'm getting under Mojave:

```
#!python

2018-10-04 20:02:35.949690-0400 Checkout[23665:468160] *** ObjC exception 'NSInvalidUnarchiveOperationException' (reason: 'Class 'OC_PythonUnicode' disallows secure coding. It must return YES from supportsSecureCoding.') discarded
Stack trace (most recent call last):
  0x00000003 (in Checkout)
  start (in libdyld.dylib) + 1
  ffi_closure_unix64 (in _objc.so) + 70
  ffi_closure_unix64_inner (in _objc.so) + 688
  method_stub (in _objc.so) + 1248
  PyObject_Call (in Python) + 98
  function_call (in Python) + 176
  PyEval_EvalCodeEx (in Python) + 2115
  PyEval_EvalFrameEx (in Python) + 40001
  PyEval_EvalCodeEx (in Python) + 2115
  PyEval_EvalFrameEx (in Python) + 41307
  objc_NSApplicationMain (in _AppKit.so) + 313
  NSApplicationMain (in AppKit) + 780
  -[NSApplication run] (in AppKit) + 699
  -[NSApplication(NSEvent) _nextEventMatchingEventMask:untilDate:inMode:dequeue:] (in AppKit) + 1362
  _DPSNextEvent (in AppKit) + 997
  _BlockUntilNextEventMatchingListInModeWithFilter (in HIToolbox) + 64
  ReceiveNextEventCommon (in HIToolbox) + 618
  RunCurrentEventLoopInMo
2018-10-04 20:02:35.952537-0400 Checkout[23665:468603] error with remoteObjectProxyWithErrorHandler: Error Domain=NSCocoaErrorDomain Code=4097 "connection from pid 23776" UserInfo={NSDebugDescription=connection from pid 23776}
2018-10-04 20:02:40.510908-0400 Checkout[23665:468601] WARNING: _endWindowBlockingModalSessionForShownService called with <NSSharingService: 0x6000000d1e20> [com.apple.share.Mail.compose] - enabled:YES for a service but we couldn't find a matching modal session!

```

So it seems that OC_PythonUnicode needs to support supportsSecureCoding and NSSharingService requires objects to be secureCoded..

I solved this problem with the following workaround: 


```
#!objecitve-c

    [sharingService setRecipients: @[[NSString stringWithFormat: @"%@", emailAddress]]];
    [sharingService setSubject:[NSString stringWithFormat: @"%@", subject]];
    [sharingService performWithItems: @[ [NSString stringWithFormat: @"%@", body], fileURL]];

```

items.title: Deprecation warnings with Python 3.7
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/246) by Ronald Oussoren (Bitbucket: [ronaldoussoren](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren), GitHub: [ronaldoussoren](https://github.com/ronaldoussoren)).**

----------------------------------------

Building pyobjc using Python 3.7 gives deprecation warnings due to the use of deprecated APIs in CPython (in particular old-style buffer APIs).

Fixing this is non-trivial, PyObjC's use of the buffer API doesn't fully match the shape of the modern API.

items.title: PyObjCClass_CheckMethodList doesn't check for NULL returned by PyObjCSelector_NewNative
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/243) by Terry (Bitbucket: [monoxygen](https://bitbucket.org/monoxygen), GitHub: [monoxygen](https://github.com/monoxygen)).**

----------------------------------------

PyObjCClass_CheckMethodList gets selector information by calling method_getTypeEncoding, passes that result to PyObjCSelector_NewNative which then calls PyObjC_FindReplacementSignature.

When method_getTypeEncoding returns NULL (documented in the objc runtime headers as a valid return value), the data passed to PyObjCSelector_NewNative and then PyObjC_FindReplacementSignature will be NULL.

PyObjC_FindReplacementSignature correctly identifies that this selector is NULL, sets the error string "Selector with NULL or too long signature", returns NULL and then PyObjCSelector_NewNative returns that same NULL to PyObjCClass_CheckMethodList.

PyObjCClass_CheckMethodList does not check for this return value or the error, and tries to add this NULL as a value to a dictionary which subsequently causes Python to crash on a NULL dereference.

PyObjC should check this return value and skip this introspection when the selector is NULL to prevent the crash (and potentially log a warning somewhere).

This issue comes up when trying to load Swift frameworks that have ObjC interfaces, due to a Swift compiler bug described in https://bugs.swift.org/browse/SR-8356

----------------------------------------

Hello,

I have an Objective C initializer initMyClass from MyClass that I’d like to use from Python with the following signature:
- (instancetype)initMyClass:(SInt16 *)dataArray descriptor:(MyDescriptor *)descriptor;

However I get a “depythonifying ‘pointer’” error when I try to use it:
>>> myclass = MyClass.alloc().initMyClass_descriptor_(array.array("l", [1,2,3]), my_descriptor)

  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>

I check it’s signature and __metadata__() and all seems well:
>>> MyClass.initMyClass_descriptor_.signature
'@32@0:8^s16^{MTImageDescriptor=qdssIiiiSB}24'

>>> MyClass.MyMethod_descriptor_.__metadata__()                                                                                                                                {'classmethod': False, 'hidden': False, 'retval': {'_template': True, 'type': '@'}, 'arguments': ({'_template': True, 'type': '@'}, {'_template': True, 'type': ':'}, {'null_accepted': True, 'type': '^s'}, {'null_accepted': True, 'type': '^{MTImageDescriptor=qdssIiiiSB}'})}

In any case I also tried running objc.loadBundleFunctions() but it couldn’t find my function:
>>> objc.loadBundleFunctions(my_bundle, globals(), [("MyClass.initMyClass_descriptor_", "^l^@")], skip_undefined=False)
Traceback (most recent call last):

Any suggestions on how I should proceed? Thanks.

items.title: Importing can sometimes fail in multi-threaded scenarios
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/236) by Max Bélanger (Bitbucket: [maxbelanger](https://bitbucket.org/maxbelanger), GitHub: [maxbelanger](https://github.com/maxbelanger)).**

----------------------------------------

We've noticed the following exception can occur (rarely) in some scenarios:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  ...
  File "ImageCaptureCore/__init__.py", line 21, in <module>
  File "objc/_lazyimport.py", line 81, in __init__
RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during iteration
```

This is possible if another thread mutates `sys.modules` during the `for` loop in `_lazyimport.py`.

items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/234) by Vangelis Koukis (Bitbucket: [vkoukis](https://bitbucket.org/vkoukis), GitHub: [vkoukis](https://github.com/vkoukis)).**

----------------------------------------

I am playing with pyobjc's wrapper for AuthorizationExecuteWithPrivileges().
The documentation says I should be able to pass "NULL" as the value of the last argument, if I don't need a communications channel:
https://developer.apple.com/documentation/security/1540038-authorizationexecutewithprivileg

However, Python segfaults if I call the wrapper with objc.NULL as its last argument.

It seems the code passes NULL properly at:
https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/src/3e43c546753b7c600c01022201d7a31b66e1487f/pyobjc-framework-Security/Modules/_Security.m?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#_Security.m-725

But then still wants to build and return a Python value from the now-uninitialized value of FILE * communicationsPipe at:
https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/src/3e43c546753b7c600c01022201d7a31b66e1487f/pyobjc-framework-Security/Modules/_Security.m?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#_Security.m-738

items.title: Segfault in Security framework: m_AuthorizationCopyRights() wrapper
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/233) by Vangelis Koukis (Bitbucket: [vkoukis](https://bitbucket.org/vkoukis), GitHub: [vkoukis](https://github.com/vkoukis)).**

----------------------------------------

Hello,

I'm playing with the pyobjc wrapper for the Security framework.
Wrapper m_AuthorizationCopyRights() segfaults when I:

1. Call Security.AuthorizationCopyRights() from Python, passing py_authorizedRights = None 
2. Press Cancel at the dialog box that appears.

On the other hand, passing py_authorizedRights = objc.NULL allows it complete without crashing.

It seems the crash happens at the point where the code attempts to translate back the rights returned from AuthorizationCopyRights() into a py_authorizedRights Python object, at lines 541-546, but I haven't had the chance to investigate further with a debugger yet.

Could it be that pressing Cancel leads to AuthorizationCopyRights() not setting the value of authorizedRights, declared at:

https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/src/3e43c546753b7c600c01022201d7a31b66e1487f/pyobjc-framework-Security/Modules/_Security.m?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#_Security.m-494

so the code at 541-546 accesses random memory?

items.title: Starting 'runConsoleEventLoop' from a secondary thread.
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/215) by WayneK (Bitbucket: [WayneK](https://bitbucket.org/WayneK), GitHub: [WayneK](https://github.com/WayneK)).**

----------------------------------------

Hi,

First, thanks for a extremely useful library, kudos.

I have a CoreBluetooth based BLE advertisement scanner working with PyObjc all ok. 
As I am putting this into a (multi-platform) Python module and I would like the main loop to be kicked off from a secondary thread created by the library, so to stay out of the way of users code.

In order to start the RunLoop using 'AppHelper.runConsoleEventLoop' on a thread I have created an Autorelease pool within the thread but am not receiving Bluetooth events.  
I /think/ I need to create and pass a new dispatch queue to 'CoreBluetooth.CBCentralManager.initWithDelegate_queue_options_' created within the same thread, the but PyObjC doesn't support dispatch_queue_t yet.

I've read that starting a runloop on a secondary thread /should/ be possible.. is it really true for Objc? is it really possible in PyObc C ?

Do I really need a dispatch_queue_t? Is there an rough estimate as to when it will be added?

Thanks,
Wayne

items.title: subclass in iOS run successfully in simulator but failed in iPhone
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/208) by iosdeveloper (Bitbucket: [__bridge_retained](https://bitbucket.org/__bridge_retained), ).**

----------------------------------------

Hi Ronald,

Thanks for your great job.
I'm trying to use pyobjc in a iOS project, following code can run in simulator:

```
import objc
from Foundation import CGRectMake
UIApplication = ObjCClass("UIApplication")
UIColor = objc.lookUpClass('UIColor')
UIView = objc.lookUpClass("UIView")

rootVC = UIApplication.sharedApplication().keyWindow().rootViewController()
rc = CGRectMake(30,70,50,60)

class MyView(UIView):
    def initWithFrame_(self, frame):
        self = UIView.alloc().initWithFrame_(frame)
        self._.backgroundColor = UIColor.redColor()
        return self

aView = MyView.alloc().initWithFrame_(rc);
rootVC._.view.addSubview_(aView)
```

But failed in iPhone, crashe in function initWithFrame, any idea?

items.title: Add ability to read bytes from objc.varlist
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/205) by Nickolas Pohilets (Bitbucket: [nickolas_pohilets](https://bitbucket.org/nickolas_pohilets), ).**

----------------------------------------

Use case: CGBitmapContextGetData returns a pointer to raw data, several MBs in size. I would like to pass it to NumPy for further processing. Currently, it gets converted into a tuple of millions of single-byte objects.

A simple solution would be adding a method `def as_bytes(self, count: int) -> bytes`.
 
Another alternative is to implement [Buffer Protocol](https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/buffer.html)

items.title: Incorrect signature of CGPDFDictionaryGetObject()
`DPyObjC_BUILD_RELEASE` is based on the running macOS version and not the SDK in use
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/203) by Max Bélanger (Bitbucket: [maxbelanger](https://bitbucket.org/maxbelanger), GitHub: [maxbelanger](https://github.com/maxbelanger)).**

----------------------------------------

In our testing, we're sometimes developing on 10.13  but using Xcode 8 (which comes with the 10.12 SDK). Despite using `xcode-select`, which properly sets `-isysroot` when building PyObjC, the `DPyObjC_BUILD_RELEASE` define gets set to 10.13. Should this not be using the SDK value from `xcrun` instead?

items.title: Some opaque types are not exported from Quartz module
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/202) by Nickolas Pohilets (Bitbucket: [nickolas_pohilets](https://bitbucket.org/nickolas_pohilets), ).**

----------------------------------------

Not exported:

* CGPDFDictionaryRef
* CGPDFScannerRef
* CGPDFStreamRef
* CGPDFStringRef

But the following types are exported:

* CGDirectPaletteRef
* CGDisplayConfigRef
* CGEventTapProxy
* CGPDFArrayRef
* CGPDFContentStreamRef
* CGPDFObject
* CGPDFOperatorTableRef

PyObjC version 3.2.1

items.title: Deprecate tuple-like behavior for structwrapper
items.body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issue/197) by Ronald Oussoren (Bitbucket: [ronaldoussoren](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren), GitHub: [ronaldoussoren](https://github.com/ronaldoussoren)).**

----------------------------------------

The wrappers for C structs in PyObjC are "writable tuples", remove the "tuple" bits (no indexed access to fields).

See documentation of attrs of why this is a good idea.

```
# We must init a NSPrintPanel() so that we can embed an AccessoryView
```
